ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the core values and heritage of the United States' Air Force.
I learned about military history and the basics of the military institution structure.
learned how to be confident in public speaking, history of the air force, and components of leadership/integrity
I learned the general history of the Air Force. We also practiced presentation skills along with the official style formatting for the Air Force.
I developed knowledge of the history of the Air Force, as well as the customs and courtesies of the Air Force.

I learned how to affectively manage time when preparing briefings, take more thorough notes, and be an active listener during class. I also had opportunities to work with classmates which I believe is crucial in an ROTC environment.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The material in this course was taught in a logical sequence.

strengths: clear deadlines/standards/light work load
weaknesses: time constraint/rush in finishing presentations

From the course's content to how Lt Col Tseng instructs us, everything felt like a real college course and required the same attention, dedication, and passion. I believe the class could improve if more team-building exercises were involved, but there were still plenty of opportunities for that outside of class at ROTC.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to other students at Yale who are interested in Air Force ROTC.
yes, if interested in becoming a better speaker/in the military
I would recommend to other First Years in ROTC at Yale.

For those interested in ROTC, Heritage and Values is essential to understanding the commitment and requirements of an officer in the United States Air Force. If one believes in the core values, is comfortable with learning from mistakes, and dedicates time and effort to this class, they will greatly enjoy and benefit from AS101.
